ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Left Cerebellopontine Angle (CPA) Tumor
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Progressive unilateral SNHL, significant decline in speech recognition, absent reflexes, abnormal ABR, and MRI confirmation of a 5 cm mass.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Initial assessment of middle ear function.
Follow-up evaluation of middle ear status.
Investigation of potential retrocochlear pathology due to asymmetry and speech decline.
Definitive imaging to visualize the CPA and internal auditory canal.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Initial evaluation at an external clinic 4 years prior revealed a borderline normal to mild flat sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear with excellent speech recognition. Middle ear function was normal.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Left ear: Borderline normal to mild, flat SNHL (20-30 dB HL).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Current evaluation at the audiology clinic shows progression to a mild-to-moderate flat SNHL in the left ear with a significant decline in speech recognition (58%). Diagnostic testing (absent reflexes, abnormal ABR) indicates retrocochlear pathology, confirmed by MRI as a large CPA tumor.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Normal (0-10 dB HL). Left ear: Mild-to-moderate flat SNHL (30-60 dB HL).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Normal. Left ear: Absent ipsilateral and contralateral stimulation at 500-4000 Hz.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Left ear: No repeatable response. Right ear: Normal waves I-IV, prolonged III-V interval (3.36 msec) suggesting brainstem compression.

tests.name: MRI
tests.result_summary: Large mass lesion measuring nearly 5 cm in the left CPA, displacing the pons.

proposed_items: Surgical removal of the CPA tumor
Long-term monitoring for other CNS tumors
counseling_actions: Explain the correlation between the large mass found on MRI and the progressive hearing loss and balance issues.
Discuss the significant degradation in speech understanding (rollover) as characteristic of retrocochlear involvement.
Explain that the abnormal ABR on the 'good' ear is likely due to the large tumor compressing the brainstem.
Counsel on surgical management and potential outcomes, including sacrifice of the auditory nerve and facial nerve risks.

red_flags_present: Abnormal ABR (absent response and contralateral latency prolongation)

escalation.rationale_short: Large 5 cm CPA tumor compressing the brainstem requires immediate surgical management.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor recovery, facial nerve function, and surveillance for other tumors.

expected_outcome: Tumor removal: The tumor was removed and the auditory nerve was sacrificed.
Facial nerve function: The facial nerve had to be grafted, but the patient regained good facial nerve function following surgery.
Neurological status: The patient has no neurological symptoms at the present time and functions well in everyday situations.
Long-term course: She subsequently developed an acoustic tumor on the other side as well as other CNS tumors and is currently being followed.
